captions.text: (Applause)
Hello, how are you? Good afternoon.
It is a huge pleasure to be here.
Yesterday talking with Estani,[br]I was having trouble
finding a title for this talk.
I had some horrible titles and just then,[br]almost in unison,
both of us thought about that line:
"I don’t know what I want,[br]but I want it now".
But, I don't want to talk about now right now,[br]first I want to go
back forty years.
Forty years ago, there was an experiment
at Stanford University,[br]a psychologist seized the fact that
Stanford University had a Day Care,[br]that his
own daughter attended,[br]and did the following:
he took the children, one by one,[br]took them to a room
and offered them a marshmallow,[br]a desirable treat
for a kid, and said,[br]"You can eat it, but,
if I leave the room and you wait[br]until I come back
-- and I'll be right back[br]-- I'll give you another one".
It's great to put four year old kids,[br]at that age
kids that are just overcoming the external
restrictions to postpone instant gratification
and are beginning to incorporate self-control.
If you like, you can search online[br]for the faces and things
kids do to avoid eating the marshmallow.
They twitch, they smell it,[br]cover their eyes,
cover their ears --[br]which has nothing to do with it --
they start eating a little bit,[br]to see if they manage
to eat a bit without the adult[br]turning around,
but finally only 30 percent of the kids manage
to postpone their immediate desires[br]and reach the 15 minutes.
And 15 minutes later the adult returns[br]and gives them another marshmallow.
And what Mischel says is very simple,
he says, "These kids are obsessed[br]with the object and if
instead they could be distracted,[br]if they could think
about something else, they'd get through[br]the 15 minutes without
any problem at all. [br]And later, since they were classmates
with his daughter, he followed up on them.[br]And he started
to see differences[br]between those that could postpone
instant gratification[br]and those who succumbed to
the more immediate desire.[br]And he saw that those that were
capable of self-control, had less
behavior problems later,[br]they did much better in
admission tests to schools, colleges.
They had less problems[br]in dealing with stressful
situations, less attention problems and less
trouble building stable relationships.
So it seems that patience against desire,
has benefits, at least benefits on a personal level.
Desire is defined as an extreme want,
a very intense wish.[br]In Spanish the root is "anxi"
related to other words we know
in Spanish.
Anxi means "hold strongly or suffocate" that is
the origin of the word.[br]And when you talk
of anguish, when you talk of angina,[br]when you talk of
anxiety medications,[br]when you talk of anger,
all these Spanish words[br]have the same root and, of course,
also have the same root[br]as the word anxiety.
Anxiety or anxiety-related illnesses[br]are the biggest mental
phenomenon or problem the world faces.
And beyond the personal issues generated
by anxiety, from a social point of view,[br]the largest
generator of anxiety is economic uncertainty.
When the economy is bad,[br]we get anxious
and for us, the economists,[br]a bad economy
an economy in bad health[br]is called "recession"
and it's clear why recession generates anxiety.
This is the average of what has happened in
Argentina every time there is a recession.
There are 333.000 new unemployed,
and more than 2 million new poor and
inequality rises by ten percent.
So, it is very clear that when the economy
doesn't work as it should, we become a
little more anxious.
And it is easy, I believe,[br]to understand the root of this problem,
why we get impatient when things don't
work, if we appeal to the logic of the marshmallow.
Let us assume we are on a highway[br]and we can take
one hundred pesos now,[br]we stop and take
the hundred pesos, but there is something[br]much more important,
something that is worth ten times more[br]is just ahead.
If we keep going slowly, we can reach
those thousand.[br]Not much more to go.
But really the capacity to see those thousand,[br]of noticing
that they are close, that we can reach them,
depends greatly on the condition of the road.
If the road is like this highway,
that is right there, we say yes, we make the effort,
we postpone instant gratification and make it
to the thousand. But if the road is like this,
its much more complicated, we don't see clearly what
lies beyond all the obstacles,
after all the accidents and maybe
instead of going down this road,[br]that is so complicated,
we prefer the 100 now.
Those cracks that you see[br]there are the recessions
in an economy.[br]And when we fall in a crack, we
can’t even see the question mark over there,
all we see is pitch black.
So it is easy to understand,[br]that when the economy
is not going well,[br]why we all get a bit impatient.
When the economy is in a recession
why we get impatient.
And the truth is that the Argentinian,[br]as far as recessions go
are sort of world champions.
We have had ever since 1885,[br]on available data,
an average of a recession every four years.
Only four times in all of our history[br]have we been able
to grow four years in a row at 4 percent,
that isn't a very high rate, anyway.
Only four times in approximately 135 years,
sorry, 115 years, have we achieved this,
in 125 years have we managed this.
Only four times, this is not normal for other countries.
Since 1975, in the last 35 years,
Argentina has had 14 recessions.
And on top of those 14 recession,[br]we had a crisis
a full blown crisis every five years.
A full blown crisis, for me,
a major crisis, a crisis like
hurricanes in the U.S.,[br]when they name them
after a woman.
We give them other names
that you can see there
but they are strong crisis,[br]and this is not the norm
in other countries,[br]but it does make us
a little more impatient.
It makes it much harder[br]for us to see what there is
if we make an effort,[br]if we persevere a little longer
and if we go a little bit further.
And when someone says[br]that we spent 14 years
-- of the last 35 -- in a recession,
it means that a person that started work
at 20, today is 55
spent 40% of their work life
inside a crack.
4 of every 10 years stuck down there.
4 of every 10 years are black.
And we are particularly world champions
at this game of recession,[br]having had so many.
So much so,[br]that for economists in Argentina,
it's probably the only country[br]where they are asked,
What do you make of it?[br]Does it look good or bad?
It is too simple a question for an economist
How, good or bad?
So one says,[br]"What to you mean with good or bad?"
Umm. Should I continue doing this,[br]hold out a bit longer
or should I buy U.S. dollars?
And that is a bit our pattern,
what happens is that this,[br]the recession, is like we
are growing, we start growing upwards
suddenly - -as Maradona would say --
somebody comes along[br]and cuts off our legs.
Have a look at this,[br]let us imagine that in 1975,
35 years ago, there were
-- it'll sound like a joke, but it isn't --
and Argentinian,[br]a Chilean and a Brazilian,
and the height of each one,[br]was the same,
and that height represents[br]the income per capita.
So, 35 years go by
and the Argentinian goes from 1,75m
to 2,45. He grew up, right?,
but also, every time he grew,
every so often, his legs got cut off.
So one says,[br]"Ok, how did the Brazilian do?"
The Brazilian is taller, instead of
2,45m, he is 3,15m tall.
and then Says, "And the Chilean?"
The Chilean looks at them from above
and is 5,60m tall.
But beyond what we lost along the way,
beyond whether or not we could have grown[br]and be a bit
taller, if this is our income per capita,
the real problem is the other thing.
The real problem is what our road looks like.
The path of a Chilean, towards growth,[br]is more or less
like this doodle you see there.[br]It isn't a straight line
going up. It gets lost occasionally
in some recessions, right?,[br]it gives a few turns
there are some crisis, the dollar goes up,[br]it goes down
but he keeps moving forward.
The data you see there is real.
That is the income per capita[br]in US dollars in Chile,
how it has evolved over the last few years.
And the Brazilian one is more or less like this:
it got lost a lot at the beginning, right?,
but then it kept on going and going
and walking, and had some detours but the
last years were mostly in a straight line.
And one says,[br]"Ok, what about ours?"
Ours, is like this.
(Laughter)
And this is real data, ok?,
this in not a doodle that a friend made for me
I told him take the GNP per capita in US dollars
of Argentina and draw a graph through time
And this is what happens, ok?
So it is true that if one says that
the road I have to collect those 100 dollars
is quite winding,
it has lots of pot holes
and many free falls,
the truth is, I don't know if I want[br]those 1000 dollars over there.
Give me something urgent,
something that will make me feel good now.
And that is how we Argentinian have become
extremely short-term thinkers
extremely short-term thinkers.
So much that I'd say we should
call it a national characteristic.
Meaning, I'm Argentinian,
I like football,
I like dulce de leche,
I love Patagonia,
I'm a fan of Maradona,
I drink Malbec, eat barbecues,
and I think short term.
(Laughter)
The rest, the future ... really,
I don't care that much about.
So it's easy to understand it[br]using the marshmallow' logic,
with the logic of the treat,
why is it that an economy that has so many jumps,
that is so volatile,
becomes an economy,
or transforms its citizens into extremely impatient,
anxious people, and they start[br]suffering more anxiety,
not only for things to happen now
but we become a bit more
complicated in our daily lives.
Recently, a friend that has lived a long time
in the U.S. visited,
and when her son got here, he said:
"Mummy, how come people here[br]don't have a happy face?"
Right? We look worried.
Now we can respond and say to the U.S.
"Now you look worried too".
But it is easy to understand why
such an economy generates a behavior
that is impatient and thinks short term.
But, I want to propose something else here,
that is: every time we think short term
it has an impact on the economy.
And every time we impact the economy
we also have an impact on society.
So I want to propose that[br]the relationship is not one-way.
from one side to the other
but also the opposite.
Umm ... you know that economists
are taught things in an overly simplified way.
Simplified means, that when we started studying
economics a long time ago,
what they told us was:
"Ok, Economy is about this;
you must maximize something".
What is that something?[br]I don't know... your benefits.
Given, that everything else remains the same.
All the rest is exactly
how you saw it at that time.
There is no reaction from anybody.
And that supposition[br]that is very strong in economics
is called: "ceteris paribus"[br]which means precisely,
"all the rest is constant".
So, for example, it would be very easy for me
to make a lot of money now,
you are all frozen,
absolutely frozen, you cannot do anything.
All the rest, that is you, is constant
and I go, one by one, and pick your wallets.
And I become rich overnight.
The only problem with that is that
it is a very unrealistic proposition
and you are going to beat the crap out of me.
and I will leave here without money and beaten up.
And this is a problem that economics had
to deal with real issues until
someone came along,[br]that is John Nash.
He's different from how you met him
in the movie "A Beautiful Mind"
with Russel Crowe, right? A little less...
he was younger than Russell Crowe[br]when he made the movie
when Nash was in school.
He did a doctoral thesis in mathematics[br]at Princeton,
at the age of 21,[br]and it only had 30 pages.
Nash is still alive and, in fact,[br]he's a genius,
that was the phrase[br]on his letter of recommendation
for admission to Princeton.
The phrase his tutor used[br]for admission to the university
for his doctorate said:
"This man is a genius".
And he came up with a very,[br]very simple idea
that helped a lot of different sciences:
biology, economics, sociology.
And it is a mathematical idea of how to find
a balance when, in real life,
there is an interaction.
And what Nash says is very, very intuitive,
which is the following:
"Something is an equilibrium[br]when after what you did
I do no want to change what I did.
And after what I did, you don't want to change
what you chose".
And the clearest example that I can think is
when you are greeting someone.
If I, now that guys are also greeting with kisses,
If I am going to greet someone and
I'm going to kiss him and he sticks out his hand
there is no equilibrium.
Somebody much change something
to reach an equilibrium.
Either he changes, because if what I did, and
we both shake our hands.
Or I change, because of what he did,[br]and we both kiss.
And anyone that has contact with women
in the Anglo-Saxon world knows what I'm talking about.
O anyone that has to greet his father in law
who is very old-fashioned,[br]surely also knows
what I'm talking about.
So this is a very, very simple idea
and its applicable to a lot of things.
So I'll propose now a game
nearly as simple and it is as follows:
I'll deal a virtual deck of cards, ok?,
and those virtual decks, from those virtual decks,
you will have to pick a card.
There is no communicating,[br]no speaking at all
to anybody. You must pick a card.
The trick is that there will be a prize
and the prize depends on how many people
choose the same card, ok?
So I'll give you 10 pesos to the power[br]of the amount of people
that chose the card. minus one, ok?
This means that if one person[br]chooses that card
I will give 10 to the 0 equals 1
and you will keep one peso.
If two people choose the same card
I'll give you ten pesos to split between two
If eleven choose the same card,
I'll give you $10.000 million[br]to split between 10,
sorry, between eleven,[br]you will leave with $900
million each, all right?
If all of us here choose the same card,
we will fix with our own money,
and I assure you there will be money left over,
the international financial crisis.
(Laughter)
So we have 15 seconds,[br]that is all, 15 seconds
to pick a card.
Remember: the card,[br]it's not your favorite number,
not the color you love,
not the one that brings you the best memories,
its the card, that you believe,
that all everybody else is going to choose.
Because if you pick the card[br]that everybody chose
we will solve many
many problems.
So I'll give you only
15 of my precious 3 minutes,
15 seconds of my precious 3 minutes
for you to pick a card and I ask you,
please, that you do this consciously.
(Silence)
Did everyone pick a card?
Raise your hand if you chose an Ace.
And who chose hearts?
Over there are a lot of possible[br]Nash equilibrium,
a lot.
Who chose the four of picks?
The three of clubs?
The two of diamonds?
Here there are a lot[br]of possible Nash equilibrium
and yet there is something[br]that leads us all
to pick a similar card, right?
It's a standard, a cultural element.
The problem is that, in Argentina,
that cultural element that brings us all together
is called crisis, right?
And when we think[br]that there is going to be a crisis,
sorry that I'm going back,
the following happens:
generally we define vice as
the moral inclination[br]of the soul towards actions
that do not conform to the moral code.
And I have a lot of issues with that definition.
One is, that as I'm economist, I have no soul.
(Laughter) (Applause)
And the second is that I cannot mathematize,
I cannot put it in numbers
and I need to assign it some number.
So I say, I'll come up with a definition
of vice that is different
Instant gratification is a vice, am I right?
That has the cost of generating a
much bigger problem in the future.
Let us imagine a simple vice: cigarettes.
A puff today and I'm happy
but the cost is the probability of very serious
illnesses further on, correct?
And I say to you:
"Ok, if the future is important,
you wouldn't smoke that cigarette".
But if you are today seated next to Gaddafi
and Gaddafi says:[br]"If you desert, I'll kill you"
and in the meantime[br]all the rebels are looking for you,
and you feel like smoking.
The question is: What will you do?
And what you'll do,[br]is light up the damn cigarette.
And you pay personal vices[br]with a personal cost
and finally with death.
But societies do not disappear like that,
they only become[br]more and more ridden with vice.
So, a society that is focused[br]on the short term
has a lot of trouble improving the quality[br]of what it provides.
A society that only produces,[br]for example,
a society that makes no effort to educate itself
cannot thrive.
A society that consumes[br]but does not save or invest
cannot improve.
A society that only thinks about short term policies
does not have any long term State policies.
And there is the definition of "populist policies"[br]that I like most
Populism is subjecting
the long term to the short term.
So if we become ever more
short-term thinkers, what we have is
a society with more vices and a worse society.
And what we must achieve, eventually,
is get out of the ace of hearts
as the ace of hearts is this;
crisis, crisis, crisis.
Only one marshmallow,[br]and start to understand
that what we must think of, in order to get
the second marshmallow,[br]is to think of progress.
And I tried to get my economists[br]to look for images
of progress but they are too young[br]and could not find them
so they chose people who could think
long term, like Leloir,
o like Favaloro
and that is the way to get the two marshmallows.
Thank you.
(Applause)
Thanks, let's see if there is equilibrium?
Lets see if there is equilibrium?
There was equilibrium,[br]there was. Don't go.
(Applause)
Don't go.
(Applause)
I was very interested in the subject of anxiety
and recessions.
Are there for example studies[br]or do you know of countries
that are culturally less anxious
or that due to their cultural habits,[br]have less economic crisis?
Meaning, looking at it the other way around.[br]You know what I'm saying?
Yes. Are there countries[br]that because of their cultural habits
have less economic crisis?
What we have now are...[br]some studies that
start to show, for example,[br]how the level
of anxiety rises in countries that are having
a big crisis, this is what is happening
in the U.S.
--The crisis is driving anxiety.[br]And the other way around?
So, for example, being anxious[br]triggers an economic crisis?
-- I put you on the spot, I'm sorry.
-- No, I haven’t found -- I think that we
are a very good example
because many times we choose shortcuts
to get benefits, whether economic or
to increase our level of consumption, etc.
And the cost is that in the end[br]something blows in our face.
Umm... the shortcut of convertibility is one of them.
The shortcut of high rates of consumption[br]that we have now
is another.[br]That breeds problems,
thinking always in the short term,[br]starts breeding
issues that finally have an impact
on the economy later on.
-- I'm convinced that all these things
are related to education.
I'd like to put you in this position:
If tomorrow you were,[br]although perhaps you don't want to, right?
But if tomorrow you were Minister of Education
what would be the three things you would do
in this country, at this moment?[br]Sorry for being...
One of them has much to do[br]with what it is easy
in the short term and hard in the long term.
That is, handing out notebooks, or netbooks, or...
I don't know how they are called,[br]because I'm not very
technology savy, as you may have seen.
But handing out computers to kids
is nowhere near proven to improve
school performance.
In all the research that has been done,[br]there are two
big things that improve school performance.
In very poor regions, to fight... parasites
so that kids can go to school and have
good health.
The second one is better teachers.
Without better teachers you cannot have...
(Applause)
a better education.
But that requires, that requires the...
it requires the long term.
Handing out netbooks is easy.
Arguing with the union is very, very hard.
-- that is one... two more.
(Laughter)
-- Get rid of parasites.
(Laughter)
There is a, there's a...[br]I have relatives in Sweden.
And there is something[br]that surprised me a lot
-- in my family there are many teachers --
Um, and the ones that live in Sweden[br]are also teachers.
And I once saw very clearly how solidarity
can be taught in school.
It is taught in school from a very early age.
They have, in the second grade, a textbook
that has no words, but a lot
of images, for example
two dogs tied to the same leash
that try to eat in two different plates
and they start by choking each other, choking, choking
until the two decide to go to one place and
then the two go to the other.
And this is something that I believe is taught,
a lot of things are taught in school
and I think that, it would be very important.
Going back to a school that teaches[br]values and integration.
-- Thank you, Great!!
(Applause)
He explains the difficult stuff, easily.[br]How great!
(Applause)
How awesome!
(Applause)
